awd_titl_txt: CICI: RSARC: DDoS Defense In Depth for DNS
awd_abstract_narration:
Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks continue to plague the Internet. Attacks have significant effects on social media, content and many other Internet services. Malicious actors are becoming increasingly sophisticated and are employing methods to hide their attack origins, amplify the size of their attacks, and use huge botnets that simply overwhelm their targets. This project directly addresses these advanced attacks by developing and deploying a defense in depth approach, called Deep Layers, to mitigate the types of DDoS attacks seen most recently. Deep Layers will be deployed to protect B-Root, the critical infrastructure that is one of thirteen providers of the Domain Name System (DNS) service for the top level (root) of Internet names that begin with www.

The Deep Layers solution to DDoS attacks integrates two approaches to filter spoofed traffic, two approaches to identify known-good traffic (hop-count filtering and prioritization of known-good clients), with the addition of a cloud-based scaling component to handle the largest attacks. The combination of these steps address an array of increasingly sophisticated attacks, ranging from those seen today to those that would be possible in the future, significantly increasing DNS resilience to DDoS attacks. The project integrates and extends several recent successful research approaches to DDoS defense and demonstrates their effectiveness on the B-root critical infrastructure. The project demonstrates Deep layers on the B-Root DNS server, and makes it available to other DNS operations as open source software. The work vastly improves the reliability of the DNS critical infrastructure, benefiting all Internet users.

por.por_cntn:
Distributed-Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks are a continuing problem in the Internet today, where an attacker makes a public service unusable by flooding it with traffic. The DDoS Defense in Depth for DNS (DDIDD) Project developed novel approaches to counteract DDoS for self-hosted services, particularly DNS (the Internet Domain Name Service). DDIDD developed several new filters to separate good traffic from bad: a novel Wild-Resolver Filter that identifies newly aggressive incoming traffic, a novel Response-Code Filter as a last-defense mechanism, and public implementations of Hop-Count filtering and in-kernel Top-Level Domain filtering (for Root DNS).

DDIDD also developed a filter selection system to automate our multi-layer defenses. DDIDD evaluated these filters for precision and recall, also releasing several of the real-world attacks we used in testing.

In addition to filtering, DDIDD explored two related methods of countering DDoS. Our datasets helped explored the use of anycast to shift DDoS traffic in joint work with the University of Twente (Netherlands). The project also partially supported LocalRoot, a system supporting pre-caching the DNS root at recursive resolvers.

As examples of DDIDD techniques at work (see first image: Rizvi19a, Table IV, reordered) shows replay of a real attack on B-Root (from 2017, a DDIDD dataset) with filtering. The top row shows high outgoing network traffic with no filtering, the middle shows DDIDD filtering handles the initial attack, but traffic peaks at time 90 minutes when the attack changes, and the right graph shows both the initial attack and modified attack are handled with the DDIDD's automatic adaptation. 

As another example (see second image: Rizvi22a, figure 11a) shows replay of a real attack on B-Root (a DDIDD-curated dataset) against a simulated 3-site anycast network. Traffic overwhelms one site (the red cross-hatched area from 0 to 300s, then defenses shift traffic to other sites where it can be handled.

Our project website is https://ant.isi.edu/ddidd/ where our filters, tools, and papers are available for download as open source. The LocalRoot service can be found at https://localroot.isi.edu/. We have published a number of peer-reviewed papers about our work, including: "Cache Me If You Can: Effects of DNS Time-to-Live", Moura et al., ACM IMC 2019; "TsuNAME: exploiting misconfiguration and vulnerability to DDoS DNS", Moura et al., ACM IMC 2021; "Anycast Agility: Network Playbooks to Fight DDoS", Rizvi et al., Usenix Security 2022, and technical report "Dynamically Selecting Defenses to DDoS for DNS (extended)", Rizvi et al., ISI-TR-736, 2019.

DDIDD datasets remain available for research use (see https://ant.isi.edu/datasets/ ). DDIDD datasets and anti-DDoS were used as a class project in graduate networking at USC, and the work has supported research by several PhD and MS students.
